instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no green light
threads.message:
PPBUS is missing
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is missing
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> near ISL is dead. Should I change <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and ISL?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no green light
threads.message: ISL will not work properly with missing <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>. Change the resistor first, verify there are no shorts and then make sure you have proper voltage on pin 2 and 3 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> before replacing, unless of course <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is causing a short in which case you should just replace that as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no green light
threads.message: Uhm no! <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is dead because of a short in <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Always change them both. Also check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22/51/52

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no green light
threads.message:
Changed <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22/51/52 are fine.

What changed: <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present this time. Still no green light, PPBUS or ACOK.
ISL also gets pretty hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no green light
threads.message: Check your soldering job, also measure resistance from F7040 to GND and report value....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no green light
threads.message: If ISL gets hot it is either soldered wrong or it was killed.
